Discussions.Discussion_Name: [FSI SoSe2024] PLAN FOR THE REST OF THE SEMESTER

Messages.Author: Giuseppe Caire
Messages.Content: Week of June 10-16: Maximum-Likelihood parameter estimation, Fisher information, Cramer-Rao Bound; Week of June 17-21: problems on maximum likelihood estimation; Week of June 24-28: Bayesian inference, sum-product algorithm, belief propagation, approximated message passing, compressed sensing (let's see what we can do); Week of July 1-5: IMPORTANT: on Tuesday July 2 during lecture time, the end of semester projects will be discussed and assigned.  YOU MUST COME TO THE LECTURE AND GET YOUR PROJECT, OTHERWISE YOU CANNOT PASS THE COURSE AND GET YOUR CREDITS.  The time to work on your project is from Tuesday July 2 to the date of your project presentation, which will be either Tuesday July 16, or Thursday July 18, i.e., in the last week of the semester.  Week of July 8-12: SECOND WRITTEN TEST ON THURSDAY JULY 11. No class on Tuesday July 9 (you are working on your project and preparing the written test).   Week of July 15-19: PROJECT PRESENTATIONS

Discussions.Discussion_Name: [FSI SoSe24] IMPORTANT INFORMATION FOR THE MIDTERM TEST

Messages.Author: Giuseppe Caire
Messages.Content: Dear Students,  for the test you can have:  1) scratch paper 2) one A4 double-sided formula sheet, where you can annotate all the formulas you want. For the rest, the test is ``closed books'', which means: you cannot have a copy of the slides and of the problems with solutions, you cannot have laptops and other devices connected to the internet, you cannot ask ChatGPT, Wikipedia, and so on .... It is just you, your pen and paper, and your formula sheet to recall things that you may find useful.  Notice that preparing a good formula sheet is a great learning opportunity, since annotating by hand formulas and theorems helps not only remembering but also understanding.   Cheers,   G
